name: Accessibility
htmlBanner:
Accessibility

Accessibility is the inclusive practice of ensuring that everyone has equal access to information, functionality, and experiences.

Users.html:
Vision impairments

Blind users

How they experience an interface...

  • As audio-only interfaces gain popularity through devices like AI assistants, users expect more and more from the audio representations of experiences.

What designers should think about...

  • Is visual information translated effectively into text? Can the image be understood through its alt text alone?
  • When possible, test all designs through a screen reader.

How this applies to everyone...

  • As audio-only interfaces gain popularity through devices like AI assistants, users expect more and more from the audio representations of experiences.

Low-vision & color blind users

Low vision can include partial sight in one or both eyes and can range from mild to severe. It affects approximately 4% of the world's population.

How they experience an interface...

  • May use screen readers, screen magnifiers, high-contrast modes, and monochrome displays
  • May have their browser font size adjusted to a larger setting
  • May not use assistive or adaptive technology at all

What designers should think about...

  • Maximize the readability and visual clarity of content.
  • Consider how the relative proximity of information changes when users magnify pages.
  • Follow keyboard guideline standards and test with a screen reader to ensure the page is read to the user logically.
  • To better understand the various low vision disabilities, enlarge screens to 400% to see if full flow and tasks are functional.

How this applies to everyone...

  • Users without disabilities sometimes need to view screens in poor lighting conditions. For example, it isn't easy to see a screen outside on a bright day. A higher-contrast design will make the screen more usable for everyone.
  • Vision worsens gradually starting around age 40, and good contrast helps this extensive demographic use your interface.

Hearing impairments

Deaf and hard-of-hearing users

How they experience an interface...

  • May rely on closed captioning and other alternative representations of audio.

What designers should think about...

  • Find an alternative way to convey information exclusively with sound.
  • Transcribe and caption all videos and animations that have meaningful audio.

How this applies to everyone...

  • All users can benefit from closed captioning. Imagine using your device in a loud or quiet environment when it wouldn’t be appropriate to turn your sound on.

Mobility impairments

Users with physical disabilities

How they experience an interface...

  • May rely on keyboards, track balls or pads, voice recognition, and other assistive technologies to interact with an interface.
  • May not be able to use a keyboard, mouse, or other pointer.

What designers should think about...

  • Design for keyboard interaction
  • Learn how to navigate using a keyboard and spend some time navigating the web and digital products like email using only the keyboard.

How this applies to everyone...

  • Many users prefer to navigate interfaces with a keyboard and no mouse for efficiency. Good keyboard navigation can help everyone be more productive.

Cognitive impairments

Users with cognitive disabilities

Functional cognitive disabilities can result in difficulties with: Memory, Problem-solving, Attention, Reading, Linguistic, Verbal comprehension, Mathematics, Visual comprehension

How they experience an interface...

  • May have limited working memory and need the information to remain visible throughout the completion of a task.
  • May experience seizures when exposed to flashing content.

What designers should think about...

  • Designers should avoid complex language, auto-playing animations and videos, and flashing animations. Designs should pass usability heuristics, such as cognitive walkthroughs, to ensure users don't feel overloaded when completing tasks.
  • Design in as linear a fashion as possible and focus on design heuristics that have to do with cognitive load and memory.

How this applies to everyone...

  • Best practices for cognitive disabilities benefit all users. Busy environments can tax your cognitive load. Aging adults may also experience a decline in cognitive abilities. Placing a low cognitive load on users reduces mistakes and improves effectiveness, regardless of their abilities.

Principles.html:
Accessibility principles

These principles are based on WCAGs core principles for accessibility.

Perceivable

Any information or component is visible to at least one of a person's senses.

Operable

All interactions and navigation are useable through a variety of input methods.

Understandable

Information and interactions of an experience must be understandable by all.

Robust

Interactions must be understandable by various assistive technologies.

Beliefs

Assume nothing is or will be perfect

Our first, second, and third attempts at making anything accessible wouldn't be great. That's okay. It's better than nothing. Accessibility is something that can't be "added on" at the end. True accessibility is about process improvement.

Moonshot: Include accessibility at every step of the design process.

Design with marginalized users

Include people with a diverse range of abilities in user testing and design whenever possible.

Moonshot: Every project seeks feedback from underinvested communities and people with disabilities.

Give people power

Allow users to customize their experiences and respect system-wide user preferences such as captions, large fonts, and high contrast.

Moonshot: Every task can be completed in a logical order using only a keyboard.

Make our spaces adjustable

Provide targets large enough to see and interact with. Try to label and describe all objects.

Moonshot: All components can be interacted with by mouse, keyboard, pen, fingertips, voice, and through an accessibility API.

Global standards and assistive technologies

About W3C and WCAG

In 1995 the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) began a collaborative process to research, write and update WCAG's digital accessibility guidelines.

W3C

World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) is the main international standards organization for the Internet. WCAG is a World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) international standard that many countries globally use for digital accessibility guidelines.

In 2018, the European Union adopted the most current published WCAG version, which is 2.1. Version 2.1 added success criteria to address mobile devices, enhance cognitive impairment and low vision assistive technology support. As new WCAG versions are released, Webex will determine when applications need to meet new success criteria.

WCAG

WCAG is a group of success criteria for digital accessibility governed by a W3C committee. Since 1999, success criteria have been added to keep up with technology to be flexible to support, and not limit, future tech innovations.

Every WCAG version has supported 3 levels. They are A, AA and AAA. Each WCAG success criteria meets one of these levels.

"The power of the web is in its universality. Access by everyone regardless of disability is an essential aspect."

- Tim Berners-Lee, inventor of WWW.

Standards Webex follows

Cisco currently designs, engineers and tests to meet WCAG 2.1 A and AA success criteria.

Standards Momentum follows

Momentum currently designs, engineers and tests all components to meet WCAG 2.1 A and AA success criteria.

What are assistive technologies?

Assistive Technologies (AT) is any item, piece of equipment, software program, or system that increases, maintains, or improves the functional capabilities of people with disabilities.

Often these technologies work together to improve users' ability to use products like screen readers and keyboard operations. Even basic HTML in websites and applications can now be read and displayed on a refreshable braille display.

Why it matters.html:
Why accessibility matters

Accessibility (AX) is the inclusive practice of ensuring that everyone has equal access to information, functionality, and experiences.

Need more than an overview?

Physical disabilities

Such as hearing loss, vision loss, or mobility issues

Cognitive

Including autism, attention deficit disorder, or dyslexia

Socio-economic

Which impacts people with disabilities in the US 2.5 times more than those without

Accessibility at Webex

Cisco's purpose is to power an inclusive future for all. Webex follows that mission closely and to heart. The Webex approach to product design always begins with people's diverse needs and work styles.

This focus on delivering inclusive collaboration experiences fuels our philosophy of innovation, leveraging AI and Machine Learning to remove the barriers of geography, language, personality, and familiarity with technology.

To us...

Inaccessible products are broken products. Accessible design is everyone's responsibility, from information and user experience design, through development to help and support.

Why it is good for design

As folks who make products for other people, we like to believe we’re intimately connected with every person using our products. But those thoughts are inherently discriminatory because we all bring silent biases with us as we design.

By building products centered on one kind of person deemed “typical” or “standard,” we fail to explicitly ensure that our products include as many people as possible.

For non-inclusive businesses
  • Companies will connect with fewer people
  • Non-inclusive products directly reflect on the company, generating negative sentiment both inside the company and in the broader industry
For non-inclusive brands
  • Companies recruit fewer candidates from historically underinvested communities
  • Companies and their products perpetuate stereotypes of and prejudice against historically underinvested communities
